./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Snowman 2.0 Documentation
Snowman is a minimal Twine 2 story format designed for people who already know JavaScript and CSS originally created by Chris Klimas. It is currently being maintained by Dan Cox.
What is the difference between 1.X and 2.X?
While working on 1.4.0, it was decided that the codebase should also move from ES5 to more JavaScript ES6 functionality. This was branched into what is now 2.X and more functionality was added from there.
The main difference for most users is that 2.X uses different event names than 1.X and also adds some new global functions.
What does Snowman offer?
Snowman does not use macros like Harlowe, SugarCube, and other story formats. Instead, it has two global objects, window.story and window.passage, that expose functionality for working with the overall story and current passage respectively through JavaScript.
The libraries jQuery, Underscore, and Marked are also included and available globally as window.$, window._, and window.marked.
Starting with 2.0, Snowman now also uses the full Babel Polyfill to simulate any missing JavaScript ES2015 functionality in the browser.
Examples
Many of the examples included in this documentation come from the Twine Cookbook and are used under the same Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.
Having problems?
Snowman is on GitHub. Report any problems or suggestions for improvements using the Issues system.
License:

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.
Documentation Version 1.7 (September 2019)

learning/links.html.title: Links
learning/links.html.body:
Links
Working with Twine means working with passages.
Passages are how Twine divides up a story into different parts. These can be scenes, like times or locations, logical sections, such as different chapters or acts, or even simply blocks of code. They provide a way to understand a story as composed of many parts.
Connecting one passage to another is done through using links. These are words or phrases surrounded by two sets of opening and closing square brackets.
[[Link]]
When used within the Twine 2 in this way, a link shows a connection between one passage and another. When a single word or phrase is included within the two sets of opening and closing square brackets, this "links" one passage to another of that exact word or phrase. The "link" is the name of that other passage.
Links can also come in different forms.
The pipe character, "|", can be used to present a word or phrase as the link text that then "connects" to a different passage.
[[Link to another passage|Different Passage Name]]
Starting with Twine 2, it is also possible to "route" links to different passages. Arrows, "->" or "
[[Link to another passage->Different Passage Name]]
[[Different Passage Name

learning/text.html.title: Styling Text
learning/text.html.body:
Styling Text
Snowman supports most (but not all) of the syntax possibilities provided by the Marked library. Any multiple-line syntax, notably variants on creating headers, is not supported. All input is rendered on a per-line basis.
Headers



Syntax
Code




Header 1
# Header 1


Header 2
## Header 2


Header 3
### Header 3


Header 4
#### Header 4


Header 5
##### Header 5



Styles



Syntax
Code




Strong
**Strong**


Emphasis
*Emphasis*



Line Items



Syntax
Code




Unordered Item
- Item


Unordered Item
* Item


Ordered Item
1. Item

learning/markup.html.title: HTML Shorthand
learning/markup.html.body:
HTML Shorthand
Snowman supports a HTML shorthand for quickly creating elements with different properties. This shorthand is broken into two parts: prefixes and suffixes:
Prefixes
After the name of the element, two different symbols can be used.

0: Sets the href property to javascript:void(0)
-: Sets the style property to display:none

Example
An empty link:
This will be empty!
A hidden DIV:
Empty link and hidden
Suffixes
After the name of the element and any prefixes are two other groups: ID and any classes. To set the ID of an element, its name must start with the hash (#) and run to the end of the opening tag or until a class name is encountered. A class name starts with a period (.) and is either after any ID or the name of an element.

#id: Sets the ID of the element
.class: Sets the class. Can be used multiple times for additional classes.

Example
A DIV with the ID of "banner".
This is a banner!
A SPAN with multiple classes.
This is large and green

learning/template.html.title: Template System
learning/template.html.body:
Templates
Through Underscore's _template() function, Snowman has a templating system that allows the use of JavaScript code to be included in passages. This comes in three main forms.
Arbitrary JavaScript
Any JavaScript can be run within a scoped context that immediately executes the code found within it using the Arbitrary JavaScript syntax of an opening, , and closing tag, %>.

Interpolation
To write a value to the passage in the current position, the interpolation syntax of an equal sign (=) following the opening tag, , can be used. This is most useful to write a variable, the result of some calculation, or the return value of a function or other related process.

Interpolate and HTML-Escaped
In those cases where a value should be both interpolated (written to the passage in the current position) and HTML-escaped, the minus symbol (-) can be used after the opening tag, . This is most useful in working with functions or with values that may contain HTML.

learning/print.html.title: print()
learning/print.html.body:
print()
Within the scope of any templated code section is the function print() provided by Underscore. This acts like the use of a value interpolation, but can be used within an arbitrary code section.
It can also be used to write any value, including HTML, within a template code section.
Example
Write this!");

%>
Note: Because print() is based in Underscore, its contexts are not parsed directly by Snowman. All markdown or other Snowman-related syntax will be ignored.

learning/functions.html.title: Functions Not Macros
learning/functions.html.body:
Functions Not Macros
Snowman does not supply any macros. In other story formats like Harlowe or SugarCube, there are bits of code that can be used called "macros." Instead of providing these, Snowman uses two global variables, window.story and window.passage.
These variables provide functions and properties that can be accessed as part of the template system built into Snowman. JavaScript is used in place of any other code either with  tags or as part of template code blocks.
window.story
Properties

name
startPassage
creator
creatorVersion
history
state
checkpointName
ignoreErrors
errorMessage
passages
userScripts
userStyles
atCheckpointFunctions

checkpoint()
passage()
render()
restore()
save()
show()
start()

window.passage
Properties

id
name
tags
sourceFunctions

render()

learning/scope.html.title: JavaScript Scope
learning/scope.html.body:
JavaScript Scope
As explained within the templates page, all Underscore template code sections are their own function scope. The same is also true of any use of  tags within a passage. These all run within their own contextual scopes.
Unlike other story formats like Harlowe, SugarCube, and others, Snowman does not provide global access to variables created. However, it does provide the additional global s that is a shorthand for window.story.state. This can safely be used as an object to save properties across passages and code sections.
When working with user-defined functions and variables, it is highly recommended to use either s or another user-defined global object such as window.setup to store and access data across Snowman passages.

htmlandcss/elements.html.title: HTML Elements
htmlandcss/elements.html.body:
HTML Elements
Snowman follows the Twine 2 standard of using  and  elements to store information about the story and individual passages. Beyond this, Snowman 2.X also uses  as the story rendering area.
During a passage transition, the contents of a  element with the class "passage" is replaced. The element with the class "passage" will always be a child of an element . However, it may not be the only child.
Example Snowman 2.X HTML Structure

    
        Test File
        
        
                  
    
    

    
        
            
                    Double-click this passage to edit it.
            
        

        
        

        
            /* Snowman code* /

htmlandcss/default_css.html.title: Default CSS

htmlandcss/workingwithcss.html.title: Working with CSS

utility/either.html.title: either()

utility/hasVisited.html.title: hasVisited()
utility/hasVisited.html.body:
hasVisited()
The global function window.hasVisited() returns if a passage has been visited (if it is a part of the story history) or not. It accepts one or more passage ID numbers or names and will return if all of the passages have been visited or not.
Single Passage ID Example
// Returns true if there is a passage with the ID of 1 in the history
hasVisited(1)
Multiple Passage ID Example
// Returns true if there are passages with the IDs of 1 and 2 in the history
hasVisited(1,2)
Single Passage Name Example
// Returns true if there is a passage with the name of "Start" in the history
hasVisited("Start")
Multiple Passage Names Example
// Returns true if there are passages with the names of "Start" and "Second" in the history
hasVisited("Start", "Second")

utility/visited.html.title: visited()
utility/visited.html.body:
visited()
The global function window.visited() returns the number of times a passage appears in the story history. It accepts one or more passage IDs or names and, with multiple passages, returns the smallest visited count among them.
Single Passage ID Example
// Returns number of visits
visited(1)
Single Passage Name Example
// Returns number of visits
visited("Start")
Multiple Passage IDs Example
// Returns smallest number of visits
visited(1,2)
Multiple Passage Names Example
// Returns smallest number of visits
visited("Start", "Another")

utility/renderToSelector.html.title: renderToSelector()
utility/renderToSelector.html.body:
renderToSelector()
The global function window.renderToSelector() accepts a valid jQuery selector and the ID or name of a passage. If both exist in the story, it will render the contents of the passage and overwrite the HTML of any elements matching the selector provided.
Example

utility/getStyles.html.title: getStyles()
utility/getStyles.html.body:
getStyles()
The global function window.getStyles() accepts one or more URLs of remote CSS stylesheets and attempts to load them. The function returns a Promise.
If loading is successful, all remote CSS rules are applied as new  elements to the  section of the story.
Example
window.getStyles("https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.4.0/css/bootstrap.min.css");

events/event_cycle.html.title: Event Cycle
events/event_cycle.html.body:
Event Cycle
As passages are loaded, different internal events are triggered.
These can be listened to using jQuery's on() function on the window or document global objects.
In 2.X, all events use the namespace "sm" and describe via verb tense the status of the event.
Story Start

sm.story.started

Passage Progression

sm.passage.hidden
sm.passage.showing
sm.checkpoint.added OR sm.checkpoint.failed
sm.passage.shown

Story Error

sm.story.error

events/story_events.html.title: Story Events

events/passage_events.html.title: Passage Events

events/checkpoint_events.html.title: Checkpoint Events
events/checkpoint_events.html.body:
Checkpoint Events
The event sm.checkpoint.added is triggered when a passage is about to be shown and a checkpoint has been set. The name property of the event object contains the passage id or name.
The event sm.checkpoint.failed is triggered when a passage is about to be shown, a checkpoint was set, but a browser security setting blocked the use of window.history for some reason. The error property of the event object contains the error message.

examples/arrays/snowman_arrays.html.title: Arrays
examples/arrays/snowman_arrays.html.body:
"Arrays": Snowman (v1.3)
Summary
Arrays are a collection of values. Each value in an array is assigned an index, which is a number that corresponds to the position of that item or element in the array. In JavaScript, arrays are zero-based, meaning the first element in the array is given the index 0. Arrays have many built-in methods and other features for your use. You can create an array by assigning a variable to the array literal, which is a pair of brackets ([]): .
Specific elements can be accessed in an array by following its variable name with a pair of brackets containing the index to check. Testing whether an array contains an element can be done using the Array#includes() function; adding new items can be doone using the Array#push() function.
Live Example




Download: Live Example


Twee Code
:: StoryTitle
Arrays in Snowman

:: UserScript [script]
(function () {
    var s = window.story.state;
    s.inventory = [];
    s.chest = ['a shield', 'a suit of armor'];
    s.chestOpen = false;
}());

:: Header
You are currently carrying: 

nothing.




:: Start


You find yourself inside a small room. In the corner, you see a sword, and decide to pick it up.


[[Continue|hallway]]

:: hallway

You see a chest here in the hallway.

Do you want to open it?

[[Open the chest.|chest]]

It's open, and there's nothing inside.


[[Move on.|dart trap]]

:: chest




You open the chest and find .

[[Okay.|hallway]]

:: dart trap

Several darts shoot out of a wall at you!


Luckily, your shield will protect you.


With no way to defend yourself, you die.

Download: Twee Code

examples/deletingvariables/snowman_delet.title: Deleting Variables
examples/deletingvariables/snowman_delet.body:
"Deleting Variables": Snowman (v1.3)
Summary
Through using the Underscore template library available in Snowman, JavaScript can be used within passages without a  tag. The delete operator can be used in JavaScript to remove a variable.
Live Example




Download: Live Example


Twee Code
:: StoryTitle
Snowman: Deleting Variables

:: UserScript[script]
window.story = {};

window.story.example = "an example!";

:: Start
What is the value of the property "example" of the object window.story? 

[[Delete the value!]]

:: Delete the value!


[[Test for value]]

:: Test for value
Does "example" still exist as part of the object window.story?

examples/lockandkey_variable/snowman_loc.title: Lock and Key: Variable
examples/lockandkey_variable/snowman_loc.body:
"Lock and Key: Variable": Snowman (v1.3)
Summary
"Lock and Key: Variable" demostrates how to create the effect of picking up a key and unlocking a door. In this example, the key is a variable (s.key) and does not initially exist in the Start passage.
When the link "Pick up the key" is clicked, s.key is changed to the value true and the door link changes from its initial response of "Locked Door" to a link to the passage Exit.
Live Example



Download: Live Example


Twee Code
:: StoryTitle
Lock and Key: Variable in Snowman

:: Start
Rooms:
- [[Front Room]]
- [[Back Room]]

:: Front Room

[[Exit]]

*Locked Door*


Rooms:
- [[Back Room]]

:: Back Room

Items:
- Pick up key

There is nothing here.


You have a key.');
    });
});
%>

Rooms:
- [[Front Room]]

:: Exit
You found the key and went through the door!
Download: Twee Code

examples/looping/snowman_looping.html.title: Looping
examples/looping/snowman_looping.html.body:
"Looping": Snowman (v1.3.0)
Summary
In programming terminology, a "loop" is a common technique for iterating, moving through one by one, some type of data. Because Snowman does not provide macros, the existing JavaScript “for” keyword) can be used to create loops. Since Snowman also includes the Underscore.js and jQuery libraries, the _.each() and jQuery.each() functions can also be used.
In this example, the s shortcut to the window.story.state variable used. A new property called “arrayInventory” is set to the series of values “Bread”, “Pan”, and “Book”. The first example uses the JavaScript “for” keyword to move through the values. The second example uses the _.each() function in Underscore.js, and the third uses the jQuery.each() function for the same purpose.
Live Example




Download: Live Example


Twee Code
:: StoryTitle
Looping in Snowman

:: Start
You have . 


You have . 


You have .

examples/markup/snowman_markup.html.body:

Summary
Snowman uses a sub-set of markdown to support style formatting. However, code highlighting and many other advanced functionalities are not available.
Live Example

:: StoryTitle
Style Markup in Snowman

:: Start
*Emphasis* or _Emphasis_.

**Strong emphasis** or __Strong emphasis__.

~~Strikethrough~~

1. First ordered list item
2. Another item

# H1
## H2
### H3
#### H4
##### H5
###### H6

Escaped code line.
Another line of code.

|    Tables     |    Are        |     Cool      |
| ------------- |:-------------:| -------------:|
| col 3         |   is          | right-aligned |
| col 2         |   is          |   centered    |
| col 1         |   is          |  left-aligned |

> Blockquotes are useful.

examples/timedpassages/snowman_timedpass.title: Timed Passages
examples/timedpassages/snowman_timedpass.body:
"Timed Passages": Snowman (1.3.0)
Summary
Made famous in Queers in Love at the End of the World (2013), "Timed Passages" uses the the _.delay() function to count seconds while checking if the timer has reached zero. If so, the window.story.show() function will immediately transition to another passage.
Live Example




Download: Live Example


Twee Code
:: Start
There are 10 seconds left.



:: World End
The world ended.
Download: Twee Code

examples/turncounter/snowman_turncounter.title: Turn Counter
examples/turncounter/snowman_turncounter.body:
"Turn Counter": Snowman (v1.3.0)
Summary
"Turn Counter" demostrates the use of the window.story.history array in keeping track of "turns" (number of passages visited). The window.story.render() function is used to "display" or otherwise include another passage at the start of each.
In this example, the length of the array window.story.history is compared to its modulo 24 value. Sometimes known as "wrap around," the modulus operator (%) is used to get the remainder of the number of "turns" (passages) divided by 24. This creates a clock where its value shows one of a series of strings representing "morning", "mid-morning", "afternoon", or "night."
By visiting other passages, the turn count is increased and the hour reaches 23 before being reset back to 0 before increasing again.
Live Example




Download: Live Example


Twee Code
:: StoryTitle
Turn Counter in Snowman

:: Start
 
Rooms:

[[Back Room]]

[[Left Room]]

[[Right Room]]

:: Back Room
 
Rooms:

[[Left Room]]

[[Right Room]]

[[Front Room|Start]]

:: Left Room
 
Rooms:

[[Right Room]]

[[Back Room]]

[[Front Room|Start]]


:: Right Room
 
Rooms:

[[Left Room]]

[[Back Room]]

[[Front Room|Start]]


:: Turn Counter

        It is morning.
     8 && hour 
        It is mid-morning.
     12 && hour 
        It is afternoon.
     16){%>
        It is night.
    
Download: Twee Code

window_story/properties/name.html.title: name
window_story/properties/name.html.body:
Name
Name is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: name
Type: String
Description: The name of the story.

window_story/properties/startPassage.htm.title: startPassage
window_story/properties/startPassage.htm.body:
startPassage
startPassage is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: startPassage
Type: Number
Description: The ID of the first passage to be displayed.

window_story/properties/creator.html.title: creator
window_story/properties/creator.html.body:
creator
creator is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: creator
Type: String
Description: The program that created the story.

window_story/properties/creatorVersion.h.title: creatorVersion
window_story/properties/creatorVersion.h.body:
creatorVersion
creatorVersion is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: creatorVersion
Type: String
Description: The version of the program used to create the story.

window_story/properties/history.html.title: history
window_story/properties/history.html.body:
history
history is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: history
Type: Array
Description: An array of passage IDs, one for each passage viewed during the current session.

window_story/properties/state.html.title: state
window_story/properties/state.html.body:
state
state is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: state
Type: Object
Description: An object that stores data that persists across a single user session. Any other variables will not survive the user pressing back or forward.

window_story/properties/checkpointName.h.title: checkpointName
window_story/properties/checkpointName.h.body:
checkpointName
checkpointName is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: checkpointName
Type: String
Description: The name of the last checkpoint set. If none has been set, this is an empty string.

window_story/properties/ignoreErrors.htm.title: ignoreErrors
window_story/properties/ignoreErrors.htm.body:
ignoreErrors
ignoreErrors is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: ignoreErrors
Type: Boolean
Description: If set to true, then any JavaScript errors are ignored – normally, play would end with a message shown to the user.

window_story/properties/errorMessage.htm.title: errorMessage
window_story/properties/errorMessage.htm.body:
errorMessage
errorMessage is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: errorMessage
Type: String
Description: The message shown to users when there is an error and ignoreErrors is not true. Any markup in the message will be interpolated as the actual error message.

window_story/properties/passages.html.title: passages
window_story/properties/passages.html.body:
passages
passages is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: passages
Type: Array
Description: An array of all passages, indexed by ID.

window_story/properties/userScripts.html.title: userScripts
window_story/properties/userScripts.html.body:
userScripts
userScripts is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: userScripts
Type: Array
Description: An array of user-specific scripts to run when the story is begun.

window_story/properties/userStyles.html.title: userStyles
window_story/properties/userStyles.html.body:
userStyles
userStyles is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: userStyles
Type: Array
Description: An array of user-specific style declarations to add when the story is begun.

window_story/properties/atCheckpoint.htm.title: atCheckpoint
window_story/properties/atCheckpoint.htm.body:
atCheckpoint
atCheckpoint is a property of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: atCheckpoint
Type: Boolean
Description: If currently at a checkpoint or not.

window_story/functions/checkpoint.html.title: checkpoint()
window_story/functions/checkpoint.html.body:
checkpoint()
checkpoint() is a function of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: checkpoint()
Parameters: {String} Checkpoint name, appears in history, optional
Return Type: (None.)
Description: Tries to add an entry in the browser history for the current story state. Remember, only variables set on this story's state variable are stored in the browser history.

window_story/functions/passage.html.title: passage()
window_story/functions/passage.html.body:
passage()
passage() is a function of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: passage()
Parameters: {String or Number} ID or name of the passage
Return Type: Object or Null
Description: Returns the Passage object corresponding to either an ID or name. If none exists, then it returns null.

window_story/functions/render.html.title: render()
window_story/functions/render.html.body:
render()
render() is a function of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: render()
Parameters: {String or Number} ID or name of the passage
Return Type: {String} HTML source code
Description: Returns the HTML source for a passage. This is most often used when embedding one passage inside another. In this instance, make sure to use  instead of  to avoid incorrectly encoding HTML entities.

window_story/functions/restore.html.title: restore()
window_story/functions/restore.html.body:
restore()
restore() is a function of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: restore()
Parameters: {String} Hash
Return Type: {Boolean} Whether the restore succeeded
Description: Tries to restore the story state from a hash value generated by saveHash()

window_story/functions/save.html.title: save()
window_story/functions/save.html.body:
save()
save() is a function of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: save()
Parameters: (None.)
Return Type: {String} Hash
Description: Sets the URL's hash property to the hash value created by saveHash()

window_story/functions/show.html.title: show()
window_story/functions/show.html.body:
show()
show() is a function of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: show()
Parameters: {String or Number} ID or name of the passage; {Boolean} if true, then this will not be recorded in the story history
Return Type: (None.)
Description: Displays a passage on the page, replacing the current one. If there is no passage by the name or ID passed, an exception is raised.

window_story/functions/start.html.title: start()
window_story/functions/start.html.body:
start()
start() is a function of the window.story global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: start()
Parameters: (None.)
Return Type: (None.)
Description: Begins playing the story.

Name: id
Type: Number
Description: The numeric ID of the passage.

window_passage/functions/render.html.title: render()
window_passage/functions/render.html.body:
render()
render() is a function of the window.passage global JavaScript variable created by Snowman.
Name: render()
Parameters: {String} Source
Return Type: {String} HTML source
Description: Returns an HTML-rendered version of the passage's source. This first runs the source code through the Underscore template parser, then runs the result through a Markdown renderer, and then finally converts bracketed links to passage links.
